text: if I told you that yoky that fabulous
dish that you always order at
restaurants only has four ingredients
what would you say to me I don't believe
you sara fantastic delicious gnocchi is
actually really easy to make really
simple and it only has four ingredients
I'm going to show you how to do it the
first thing you want to do is cook I
think this is two and a half pounds of
russet potatoes you want the kind that
has all that starch so russet are baking
potatoes or Idaho potatoes cook them in
their skin so they don't absorb too much
water and then peel them as soon as
they're cool enough to touch but still
warm if you let them cool in their skins
they'll get soggy and starchy and your
gnocchi will be heavy and gummy those
are all the tips I have you can come
back when we're done see ya this is a
ricer this is actually a really
humongous ricer they come in all
different sizes and shapes but basically
it's something that presses the potatoes
right through them
causing them to turn into the most
fabulous texture it's great for making
mashed potatoes take your potato place
it in the hopper and then press it
straight through it's fun it's just like
pressing one of those things through the
play-doh except for this is food and
it's delicious you could also grate the
potatoes in the coarse whole of a box
grater if you don't have one of these or
you could use a food mill the potatoes
need to be completely cool before you
continue on so spread them out on your
work surface and just leave them to rest
for you know 30 minutes or something
like that I'm not going to lie it's a
little time consuming but it's very easy
so once they're completely cool then you
can add one in 3/4 cups of all-purpose
flour 2 teaspoons of salt and then one
egg just whisk it pour it over Oh make
sure you catch it and then knead
everything together the egg starts
running everywhere don't worry just make
sure it doesn't run right off the table
uh yeah knead it until it comes together
into a dough I have yoky all over my
hands right now
you should dust your hands with a little
bit of flour to continue kneading and it
won't even stick to your hands anymore
so you want to knead this until it's
smooth but not elastic if it gets
elastic they're going to be chewy and
dense you don't want them chewing and
dense but how do you tell how do you
know what I do is I just keep kneading
it until I think it's ready and then I
pinch off a piece and I have some water
boiling and I just test it in boiling
water drop it in if it stays together
it's done if it disintegrates apart then
just need it a little bit more I can see
that they're done so I'm going to stop
kneading what I do now now that it's all
needed is cut it into eight pieces I
mean it just helps if it's in smaller
pieces just take one piece of your dough
roll it into a rope about a half-inch
around and if you've kneaded it enough
it will roll and be really pliable but
it won't spring back if it's not needed
enough it'll probably break apart and
that'll just tell you you need to knead
it a little bit more cut the rope into
half-inch pieces then take a fork and
place the tines of the fork on your
surface with the back part up get a
little bit of flour on your hand and
then roll little half-inch pieces down
the tines of the fork to get that
classic gnocchi shape it's probably
going to take a few for you to get the
hang of it they're really fun this is
one of those things get your family
involved they'll like doing it kids like
it especially if you're not overly
particular about how they turn out
you don't yell at your kids we're
getting the wrong shape dust a baking
sheet with flour and then you can just
transfer your finished naoki to the
floured sheet and then continue working
until you have them all done now you
just cook them add some salt to already
boiling water that's been boiling for
about 45 minutes waiting for me to make
these and then drop them into the water
don't crowd your pan don't crowd your
pan you can do this in batches and then
just let them cook until they float to
the surface
like any dumpling or ravioli or
tortellini or anything like that
and it won't take long a couple minutes
and they'll be done and they'll be ready
to eat and you'll be able to say I made
these stand around staring at your work
loving that you made these yourself
that's what we try to do here at

plus just the knowledge that they're so

don't forget the grated cheese ever my
